column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=custom.Span|label
#T_RL=custom.Relation|label|BT_custom.Span
#Text=These lodgings have spaces, like streets, between them, large enough to give the
#Text=bees a free passage in and out; and yet narrow enough
#Text=to preserve the necessary heat.
#Text=The mouth of every cell is defended by a
#Text=border, which makes the door a little less than the inside of the cell,
#Text=which serves to strengthen the whole.
#Text=These cells serve for different
#Text=purposes: for laying up their young; for their wax, which in winter becomes
#Text=a part of their food; and for their honey, which makes their principal
#Text=subsistence.
#Text=It is well known that the habitation of bees ought to be very
#Text=close; and what their hives want, from the negligence or unskilfulness of
#Text=man, these animals supply by their own industry: so that it is their
#Text=principal care, when first hived, to stop up all the crannies.
#Text=For this
#Text=purpose they make use of a resinous gum, which is more tenacious than
#Text=wax, and differs greatly from it.
#Text=This the ancients called Propolis: it will
#Text=grow considerably hard in June; though it will in some measure soften
#Text=by heat; and is often found different in consistence, colour and smell.
#Text=It has generally an agreeable aromatic odour when it is warmed; and by some
#Text=it is considered as a most grateful perfume.
#Text=When the bees begin to work
#Text=with it, it is soft, but it acquires a firmer consistence every day; till
#Text=at length it assumes a brown colour, and becomes much
#Text=harder than wax.
#Text=The bees carry it on their hinder legs; and some think it is met with on the birch, the willow, and poplar.
